Another glorious sunny day greeted us. We were all happy that we had an easy day's riding.... well compared to the previous days. We had another 'Eat everything' breakfast..... better than yesterdays. We rate the Woolpack Inn highly, 5 out of 5. We first re-traced some steps, back up the hill of overgrown foliage, which some little people insisted on walking! We eventually got to the excellently named Spy Bush Lane. It was open, sunny and not another sole insight.... and to top it all we had 2 miles of downhill to Abbotstone.

Spy Bush Lane Going Up

Spy Bush Lane Going Up 2

Sunny sign in Abbotstone

We then picked up the River Itchen and a tonne more gates and styles to negotiate. That is one thing we shan't miss. Even the walkers were going quicker than us. We looked a bit inexperienced as we all stood by the side of a field of cows daring each other to walk through. Then some walkers nonchalantly walked through leaving us looking a bit stupid.

Field by the River Itchen

Easton, what a lovely looking village, well the cottages all seemed to have thatched roofs, climbing plants and white walls. Postcard type of stuff. Following the Itchen, Katie slipped into the nettles and we went through some not so nice parts near motorways and main roads. Eventually we popped out by the 'The Bishop On The Bridge' and saw civilization again. Not really seen many people over the past 2 days. Anyway we parked our bottoms outside the cathedral and had a McDonalds celebration meal.

Dream cottage in Easton

More gate negotiating

River Itchen in Winchester

End of the ride at Winchester Castle

Checking the train times we had to rush to last bit to the Castle. Daddy got a bit short with the station guard as the machines didn't work and there was a queue at the ticket office. Fortunately the train was late. Daddy then instinctively told a man who was trying to be accommodating to be 'quick', as we were holding up a late train as we were piling in. The man huffed and rolled his eyes. Daddy apologised and explained!

Overall a successful trip. Super proud of everyone for completing the journey, especially Jessica on her small bike. Well done.

Route

We awoke stepping across the hallway for a lovely cooked breakfast. It setup us well for the day ahead. Like yesterday we weren't sure on the total mileage, thinking it'll be around the 20 mile mark. Mmm how wrong we were. Anyway there was a bit of a dispute over the cost of the hotel with the hotel owner, a case we later put forward to Expedia. Essentially we were quoted one price, but paid 37 more. We later complained to Expedia and got a refund!

Determined that this set back was not going to ruin our day, we re-traced our steps so we could re-join the book route again. Easily said that done. We hit a bridle path in a farmers field, and it was covered in stinging nettles. We didn't react too well, poor Jessica seemed to react the worst of all. It must have taken half an hour to get 200 metres. Still we survived and carried on eastwards. Then another field and the main road, A327, where we waited to cross the road, however, Jessica slipped into a nettle bush and screamed like you've never heard before. So much so that a lady came rushing out of her shop opposite. We looked for doc leaves and sat down. It took 5 or 10 minutes for Jessica to stop crying. The very kind ladies in Eversley Antiques Barn helped us by going home to get some antihistamine cream and some flapjacks! This helped and after half an hour of recovery we were off again. It was past 11am and we had travelled just 3 miles!

Jessica's leg after being stung

Recovering after being stung

We went through Warren Heath on our way to Hartley Wintney. As we approached Hartfordbridge there was a dog barking in a farm which had scared a fully grown deer, who ran and leapt right in the air immediately in front of us at a rate of knots. It was a sight to behold. Wow.

We finally reached Hartley Wintney, stopped for lunch and visited the sweet shop.... as well as the Cricketers pub.

Warren Heath

Bridging the gap

Someone put a sweet shop on our route!

The Cricketers, Hartley Wintney

Four hours in and we left the pub and we had only travelled 8 miles. We went passed the first of four St Mary's churches and headed south. We reached the Basingstoke Canal having gone over a number of gates and styles. We could finally make some progress along a gateless, flat canal towpath.

St. Mary's Church

Summer Fields

On to the Basingstoke Canal

We reached the end of the navigable canal at Greywell and in reality we were only half way in terms of mileage, maybe even less considering the hills we now had to climb! It was gone 4pm and morale was low. The realization of how far we still had to ride had set in and a concerted effort was made to make good progress. There was still the usual hurdles, including a massive muddy puddle which needed to be negotiated.

We struggled through Tunworth and Winslade. The weather was still good. It was the not knowing how far was left that was a sapper. Daddy underestimated.... It was always 12 miles to go it seemed! Due to the slow progress it was decided at Preston Oak Hills that we should go the quickest route to the hotel. This meant predominantly road riding now for the remaining 7 miles which pleased us all. Mummy conceded and vowed to come back another time to follow the off road route. Quick progress was made until we got to the final 2 miles where there was a long uphill section and an off-road bit!

Cutting through the bush

Come on Mummy only 2 miles to go

We finally made 'The Woolpack Inn' at 7:30pm. Thank goodness it was a nice rural pub which done us an evening meal and some much needed drinks. We had lost a number of water bottles during the day. They must have fallen off the bike when lifting over the gates. The rooms were excellent. We had a double and a king size bed to share between the five of us. After our baths we settled down. Daddy and Katie watched New Zealand Grand Designs whilst the rest of us watch BGT.

Route

Well earned evening meal

We arranged a 3 day bike trip across Berkshire and Hampshire, called the Three Castles Walk, taking in Windsor, Odiham and Winchester. We've prepped by getting Ben a new-ish bike, Katie borrowing Lily's, Daddy mapping the route on the phone and Mummy has booked a couple of hotels.

We left at around 9:10 and cycled down to Frimley station. First whoops moment was Ben left his helmet at the station which Farmor later picked up. People were kind on the trains helping us on to and off the trains with the bikes. We first changed at Ascot, then Staines and finally rolled into Windsor Riverside just past 11am. The weather was changeable, but mostly dry.

Frimley Station

Chatting on the train to Windsor

The girls felt a bit claustrophobic by castle around Windsor. Lots of tourists as you can imagine. Bikes were not permitted on 'The Long Walk' so we detoured past Windsor football club and into Windsor Great Park. Jessica wasn't really getting into it. She would go very slowly and even walk when her enthusiasm was down..... and this behaviour started very early. Gordon Bennett, this was going to be a long three days!

Windsor Castle

We stopped off for an early lunch half way up a hill, under a tree whilst the rain poured. Thankfully it was a passing shower. Spirits were lifted as we went through the wide roads and some down hills! Life was good again. We stopped off and looked down 'The Long Walk' back towards the castle. We escaped one royal park, into another royal area; Prince Andrew's gaff at Sunninghill - this wasn't so impressive but we had a quick peek of the 'Great Pond'. Crossing the road, we hit the start of the old mile course at Ascot. Interesting to see the old concrete pillars which helped stop enemy aircraft using it as an airstrip during the war. Access to the middle of the race course is open to the public, so we ventured through, stopping off to watch some cricket on the way.

Early lunch stop in Windsor Great Park

The Long Walk

Jessa the speed demon

Pink cottage at edge of Windsor Great Park

We were still making slow progress but we were all up for the adventure. We stopped off at Englemere Pond for some refreshments before crossing Whitmore Bog, Swinley Park and then onto Swinley Forest. We won't mention the stop or non-stop at the Woodcutters pub! At Swinley Forest we stopped at the Look Out where Katie and Ben saw some friends who they played with whilst we had another ice cream stop! 25km achieved so far.

Next we trekked Swinley Forest showing Mummy where Ben had fallen down Gravel Hill a month before and the new mountain bike area that has been chained off because it's too dangerous. Katie whilst having a 'bathroom break' in the woods left her make up bag, so Daddy had to go back to go and collect.

We exited out of Bracknell Forest and into Broadmoor territory which of course got Katie's anxiety juices flowing. We were ordered to hurry on. And now we came across the first of the gates, styles, obstacles to stop bikes! Daddy's duty was to negotiate 5 bikes around each of these! At first quite fun, but the novelty quickly wore off! One set of obstacles was the railway line (36km) which we crossed near Ambarrow Court. Unfortunately Daddy dropped his phone and it cracked the screen! Arghhh.

By the time we got to Tri-Lakes we were ready to stop and wished our hotel would come to us, rather than vice versa. Mummy led us into someone's big property in Moulsham Green. The Indian man came out and was most helpful. Mummy was almost arguing with him, saying the book instructs us to go this way. The man helped us, and Mummy mis-read and agreed with the man in the end.... and felt a bit embarrassed about making a small fuss!

Finally we made it to the main road in Eversley and tried 2 pubs who had very similar menus and similar prices before settling on the third pub, The Golden Pot. We collapsed and sat down for a lovely big meal. Partly to celebrate Mummy's passing of her nursing exam.

Just up the road was our hotel, the Kingsley. It looked lovely and there were 5 beds for us. We showered, watched TV and slept well.... although Mummy complained a lot of her aching muscles and sore bottom!

Route

Daddy, Ben and Farfar went up to Wembley to watch Reading take on Huddersfield for a place in next years Premier League. The only previous Wembley visit for Ben was an England friendly. The atmosphere was totally different for this encounter.

We took up Phil Roe's Dad and nephew, Matthew. We drove to Hillingdon and stopped for a greasy spoon before catching the tube. The language was quite colourful on the train. An almost capacity crowd poured up Wembley Way. We sat separately from Phil and his family as tickets were hard to come by.

Wembley Way

The game itself was pretty dull. Reading played possession, non risky, slow build up, park the bus type football. Not very easy on the eye.

After 90 minutes and then a further 30 minutes of extra time it ended at 0-0. Penalties! Reading had it all in their hands 3-1 up.... and somehow they missed the remaining 2 pens and lost 4-3. Half the stadium emptied quickly.

Despite a poor result and game, it was an experience for Ben... and nice to share it with Farfar and the Roe family.

Farfar and Ben enjoying themselves

Wembley Stadium almost full

We dropped Jessica off at Emma's for basically the day. She had Grace's birthday party in the middle of the day. They went to Jakes at Trilakes where they played on the softplay and went around the petting farm. Emma looked after her for the rest of the day.

The rest of us went down to Pulborough with the Kayak and me up with: Ma ma, Pop Pop, Ellie, Rachel, Jon, Richard and a couple of Jon's friends. The brave few kayaked to Houghton bridge, 8 miles down stream. Ben travelled with Daddy, however he decided on the 'relaxed' approach. It was a really sunny day, a bit of a head wind, but really nothing much to complain about. The party met with Ma Ma and Mummy at Houghton Bridge where we stopped for some refreshments. Ben swapped out for Katie, after his dismount was far from easy. Ben managed to bang his knee and cut his hand in an aborted attempt to land on the other side of the bridge!

The final 4 miles went quickly and the scenery was a little more varied with nice overhanging trees. The Black Rabbit pub was the final destination where we all met up and had a nice pint of beer in the sunshine! Route

Watched by the cows

Katie doing the second stint

The dream team

The motley krew

Pop Pop and Auntie Ellie at Houghton Bridge

title.value: River Run Kayak, Jessica at Grace's 10th Birthday party

info.content:
In the morning Daddy was too injured for parkrun, and Mummy went off to complete her first solo smoking clinic effort which she enjoyed.

In the afternoon we all travelled to Ikea, Theale where we were on a mission to get some bedroom furniture for: Katie: Bed, pictures and desk. Jessica: Wardrobe, pictures. Mission accomplished, although we still do not know how we persuaded Daddy to allow Katie and double bed. We were 650 lighter!

In the evening Ma Ma and Pop Pop come to stay the night. We watched TV, whilst Daddy went over to Farmor's to clean her bike!

title.value: Smoking Clinic, Ikea, Ma Ma, Pop Pop Sleepover

info.content: Daddy went for a 4 miles run today which he completed at a leisurely pace. However, the after effects were not good. Wednesday and Thursday were spent hobbling around. A doctor's appointment has been booked for Tuesday!
Jessica starts Netball club at lunchtimes with the year 6's running it.

After church we went to Cranleigh for a Scarecrow hunt run by the village. We went into a small grocery shop to collect the sheet, then went around looking for scarecrows. The first was in a nice furniture shop, the rest were dotted around a council estate. So basically Mummy was enthusiastically walking around 50 yards ahead of everyone else who were not really enjoying the scarecrow experience. Still we all took the mickey out of Mummy and remained in high spirits. Another 3 hours of life we are not going to reclaim!

Later in the afternoon all four grandparents visited us which was very nice.

Cranleigh Scarecrow walk

In the morning Daddy went to parkrun and competed in his 202nd run. However, after 4km he was reduced to walking as his knee was in a lot of pain. After a few minutes it felt good again, so cruised in slowly.

Jessica left at lunchtime for Heidi's birthday party. They went shopping in Primark with 10 each and went to the cinema to watch A Dog's Purpose.

The rest of the family ventured to Alton and the Elder BBQ. It was nice to see the Glidewell's and Sanders' there too. We had a large BBQ, a game of Piata, copious amounts of trampolining and a dash of 90's dance music.

Children's picnic

Piata

Godmother and her god daughter

title.value: parkrun, Elder BBQ, Jessica at Heidi's 10th birthday party

info.content: Ben was put forward by head of year, Ms Rushby to go and see the headmaster for hot chocolate and chocolate biscuits at break time in the conference room! A handful of year 7 children were selected. All boffins Ben said. Mr Major (the head) asked one thing you liked about the school and one thing to improve. Ben answered that he enjoyed maths and that he would improve the queueing at lunchtime, where year 11 children push in. Well done Ben.

In the morning we had church as usual. Katie however went to Thorpe Park again this time with Alice and Catherine. She braved Colossus 3 times.

Meanwhile the rest of us went over to Reading to pick up a second hand bike for Ben - which is slightly better than the one he currently has. Straight from there we went to Eton for walk 91. It was a gloriously sunny day, nice to be meandering with the tourists north of the river on this 2 miles outing. Route

Hideaway as part of the college ground

Castle shot

title.value: Walk 91: Eton, Katie to Thorpe Park... again!

info.content:
In the morning Ben had his final match of the season, playing Camberley Rascals. Ben knew most of the opponents from school, even some in his class. To heighten the importance of the match, if Camberley drew or won the contest, they win the league. So it was Mytchett's job to spoil the party. 0-0 at half time and Camberley were in charge, but a stout Mytchett defence, which included Ben at right back kept the score equal. Tensions were running high on the side lines from the Camberley management. They had ringers from a better Camberley team and a full 4 subs. However, wonder-kid, Oliver had a rare foray into the opposition box and poked the ball home. 1-0 Mytchett with 20 minutes to go. Some strong tackles and heroic defending saw the game out stopping Camberley from winning the league. Tears were spilt on one side of the pitch, whilst on the other euphoric rejoice as the Mytchett players turned in their best, cohesive team performance of the season. Well done chaps.

We returned home for lunch with the Elders who popped over for a couple of hours to play.

The rest of the afternoon was spent doing gardening, painting, teaking the garden furniture.

title.value: Ben exciting football, Elder over for Lunch

info.content:
In the morning Katie departed for Thorpe Park with her friends. She has just bought a season pass allowing her access through out the year.

Meanwhile Lily and Jess played teachers and Barbie's all morning after having pancakes for breakfast.

Later in the afternoon we went down to Westgate (near Chichester) to surprise Jon for his 40th birthday. It was nice to see the Glidewells, Sanders and Elders. We had a kick about in the back garden with all the boys.

Jon blowing out 40 candles.... well almost

title.value: Jon's 40th Birthday surprise, Katie to Thorpe Park

info.content:
As Daddy was injured he was reduced to being a frustrated spectator. However, the rest of us ran the 2.5km course. Ben and Katie ran in at 13:10, whilst Mummy and Jessica got 15:08. Well done.

Pre Race

Sibling Race

Medal shot

Later in the afternoon we went off to Swinley Forrest and met with the Elders who joined us on Walk 90. In the book it reported to be 2 miles, in reality it was double that. Fortunately we had our bikes to stem the mutiny. Still I think the children had fun despite their protests. Route

Jessica balancing

The cousins

Beautiful mummy

Ladies of the lake

Climbing trees over the lake

Bikers

We all returned home for a BBQ, then Ben stayed over at the Elders for the night, whilst Lily stayed to play with us girls and watch While You Were Sleeping.

title.value: Frimley 2.5km Run, Walk 90: Swinley Forrest with Elders, BBQ, Lily-Ben swap

info.content:
Mytchett made it a record 3 wins in a row at Beacon Hill Sports with Ben playing in his un-favoured right back position. Oli weighed in again with all 4 goals in the 4-3 victory.

Half time team talk

At lunch we went to Farmor's who had a birthday (69) celebration lunch. All sorts of food from Baked Beans to Smoked Salmon, catering for all sorts of refined palettes! Us children were set a team, timed, initiative test by Farfar. Fortunately we passed and collected our prize. We ended the afternoon with a game of Coppit.

Make 5 triangles task

In the evening Mummy went out with Lindsey, Paula and Silvy to Prezzo's for a meal. We all snuggled up, toasted marshmallows over the fire and ate them with melted chocolate and watched Britain's Got Talent.

Jess and Ben snuggle up together

As a celebration for delivering 7.7.5 before Christmas, Daddy and his department went for a experience day at Thruxton race circuit. In the morning he went on the skid pan, then 4x4 followed by 3 laps driving a Porsche Cayman. The highlight was undoubtedly the lap as a passenger as a pro drove around. How the tyres stayed on the car and in one piece was amazing. It was fantastic.

In the morning Daddy went on a longish bike ride. His aim was to do 50km in two hours in the countryside to the west of Farnham. He managed it, but decided that was the last action on the legs. The knee is just getting worse rather than better. So now Daddy is injured for the next 3 weeks! Route

After church Ben was dropped off in Camberley for Yuvraj's 12th birthday party. First up ten pin bowling, which Ben came last in, then on to Frenchies for eat as much you like.

The rest of us went on walk 89, a short Windsor tour. Mummy parked in a cross hatched bay and got us a parking ticket! Anyway we had a nice walk around. It was quite a laugh, Daddy was trying to embarrass us all the way around! Route

King and his princesses

Shortest street in England apparently

'The Long Walk', but not on this occassion

Katie grabbed herself a soldier

title.value: Windsor Walk 89. Yuv's 12th Birthday Party. Injured!

info.content:
In the morning Ben had a football match against Cove. Mytchett kept a clean sheet for the first time this season and won 2-0.

Celebrating after

After lunch Mummy and Daddy travelled to Oxford Circus and wandered around Soho, stopped for a cup of tea in Yumchaa which was rather nice before continuing. Mummy gave Daddy 'Secret Cinema' tickets to watch Top Gun in the posh, Courthouse hotel. It included Champaigne as an aperitif. Neither could remember the details of the film from the previous time they watched the movie. It was good to re-watch. After, they went to have an Italian. They had a conversation with the waitress about Daddy's lazy eye which she noticed! Nice.

Yumchaa Tea

Courthouse hospitality

Meanwhile, Auntie Charlotte came over to look after us, later to be joined by the Elders. We had fun playing all afternoon.

title.value: Ben Football, Secret Cinema London, Char and Elders Babysit

info.content:
We met with the Sanders at Devil's Punchbowl, a National Trust site where there was an Easter Egg hunt, similar to what we have done in previous years. However, this was a little disappointing as the trail latest about 300 yards and it was all over in 10 minutes. Still we picnic'ed (now a verb) and caught up, which we haven't done for a long time.

Devil's Punchbowl Lineup

Tree Monkey

Totum Pole

title.value: Devils Punchbowl Easter Trail with Sanders

info.content:
We all got up for the 6am church service which was held on top of Frimley Green Rec hill! Even Daddy sacrificed a lie in to join the two roman centurions, a fire and a congregation of about 20 for the 40 minute service.

After we headed back home for Easter breakfast.

Easter Brekkie

Egg Lineup

The Weston's, Maisey's and Elders then came for Roast Pork lunch which went down very nicely, if a little manic.

After we went bowling with the rest of the Barnett family to celebrate Howard's 60th birthday. We had all six lanes booked out.

We then had an egg auction down at Frimley Lodge park and had a little play with the frisbee and football. Here we learnt that Ma Ma had a mini stroke during the week much to the dismay of Laura and Ellie who are forcing them to move closer to us.

Trying to get the children to line-up for a family under 14s photo was quite difficult, especially with some disruptive adults about!

Lodge Park fun

Kids lineup

After it was back to our house for some more Egg hunting in the back garden, a trampoline show from Katie and Jessica and a nice relaxing cup of tea in front of the fire!

Egg fun

title.value: 6am Church, Weston's For Lunch, Howard's 60th Bowling

info.content:
Daddy wanted a low key affair for his 200th parkrun. Not a major milestone in parkrun eyes (no t-shirt), but still it equates to 4 years of running. Daddy ran with both Mummy and Katie! Jessica and Ben were supporting from the side lines.

Daddy and Katie finishing

We then split, the girls went to the Stoddart household for an Egg hunt and a general chit chat. All the mum's were concerned about their teenage daughters in one way or another and Mummy thought about Katie and how we did not have any worries about her. She's a lovely, happy girl.... generally!

Daddy met with his parkrun friends at the Canal Caf as usual and was given a 200 cake!

parkrun 200

In the afternoon we all went off to Chertsey where Ben was going to be mascot for the match against Camberley. The manager told people that Ben was the new winger! Ben had a one to one with Chertsey goalkeeper who took the time and trained with him for 20 minutes or so, giving him tips and making him feel really good.

Ben warming up the keeper

Ben shaking hands

Chertsey went on to lose the game 2-0 in a fairly dull contest. Thanks Farfar for arranging.

title.value: parkrun #200, Stoddart Egg Hunt, Ben Chertsey Mascot

info.content:
In the morning we had an Easter workshop at Church, which the Teales joined in with.

We then had the Fars, Susan and Graham over for a BBQ lunch and our first lot of Easter Egg giving.

The BBQ Krew

We ended the afternoon with a game of Trivial Pusuit which Jessica won!

Not so Trivial Pusuit

In the evening we all sat in front of the TV and watched Forrest Gump for the first time. It was rated quite highly for the young folk, if a little sad.

Old and new mascots

Alice came over to stay with us for a couple of days, whilst Katie went to share her time with Summer in Gravesend. Katie sounded like she had a great time. She went on the Pedlos at Bluewater, then today went to Southend to play on some of the fairground rides and walk along the sea front.

Southend

Katie and Summer

We children all agreed to go with farfar and farmor to The Black Country Museum, but thought it was indoors with things to see behind glass cases, and so maybe be a bit boring. It was not until we got near the place that we realised it was an outdoor museum, about the size of Frimley Green with real houses and shops showing what life was like over 100 years ago. There were also old fashioned buses and trams and activities, so it turned out to be great fun.

Old fashioned fairground

The museum is situated to the north west of Birmingham and this involved a lot of travelling including the longest train ride the two girls have ever done. Ben had previously been to York by train. First we caught a train from North Camp to Reading, then another to Birmingham. Next was a modern tram ride to the suburbs and to finish, a bus ride to the museum. It took almost four hours each way but we enjoyed travelling on the tram and the long distance express trains each way, that had a buffet on board.

Hanging around on street corners

The day was concluded just before eight in the evening by calling in to the Frimley Green Dominos Pizza shop on the way home for supper. It was a long but memorable day with fine weather all the time.

In the morning we went to church, except Daddy and Jessica who went off Kayaking early to Chertsey. They did the traditional Abbey River loop to Penton Hook lock, then back down the Thames to Chertsey bridge. It was the first time Jessica had attempted the loop. She did a bit of paddling at the front of the vessel. There were the usual obstacles of fallen trees, grounding on the shallows, a lock and even a pair of swans which they had to negotiate around. Route

Grounded Jessica

Kayaking pair

In the afternoon Ben and Daddy went of mountain biking. Ben wanted to attack the Lookout end of Swinley Forrest. They embarked on the 'blue' trails starting on number 1 and got as far as 8. Ben loved it, especially going around the high, fast burns. He was very brave as his bike is not built specifically for this terrain. No suspension! The pair were running out of water, so decided to head back. They got as far as going down the final Gravel Hill, then Ben hit a stone, lost balance and crashed. He lay on the ground with the bike a few feet further along the trail. He had scraped his arm and leg. Lucky he was wearing long trousers. Luckily the injuries were reduced to just cuts and scrapes. Hope this does not deter him! Route

Ben looking proud after a trail run

Ben and Daddy

Injuries

title.value: Church, Jessica Kayak River Abbey and Thames, Swinley Bike Crash

info.content:
In the morning Daddy ran with Mummy around parkrun. It was Mummy's first 5km attempt in a long while and they came in at about 32 minutes. We then picked Jessica up from a sleepover from around her friends house.

Mummy, Daddy and Natasha parkrunning

After lunch we went on Walk 88, much to the delight of the children! From the Berkshire walk book we had the Finchampstead loop around Horseshoe Lake. The weather was glorious, not a cloud in the sky. We sat for ice creams around the lake, played Pooh sticks and climbed trees over the River Blackwater. Route

Katie enjoying the views

Ice creams

Pooh sticks

At the age of 9.5 years, Jessica braved getting her ear pierced. She was very excited about the prospect and with the result. Very important to her.

Jessica Ears Pierced

It was a beautiful spring day. Deep blue skies and a decent temperature. Daddy was first out of the house, meeting up with Tim and his friend for an explore of the Tunnel Hill and Deepcut area on mountain bikes. Despite being on the doorstep, Daddy has not really explored too much these areas, especially for bike tracks. It was a long session, and the Santa Cruz bike was fantastic again. Route

After church, Ben was so tired he went to bed and slept for 6 hours plus. It was a shame as that put pay to a family walk. However, Jessica's friend, Grace knocked and asked if she wanted to go to Alice Holt taking the bike. So she did and spent most of the afternoon playing on the apparatus and cycling.

Meanwhile Daddy is trying to get the back garden in a respectable state. He's spent the evenings after work weeding, today he planted a couple of more flowers and mowed the lawn.

title.value: Tunnel Hill MTB, Church, Ben Sleep, Jess Alice Holt Bike, Gardening

info.content:
Busy day, all doing different stuff. First off Ben slept over at Ma Ma and Pop Pop's and had a McDonalds last night. It was part of Joey's birthday present. It's now traditional to have a 'shop till you drop' session. So Ben and Joey went to Lakeside this morning, Ben getting some new tracksuit bottoms.

Meanwhile Katie went with her 'acting' friend Catherine and her mum to help at Heatherside Community Centre to do some craft for kids in aid of Marie Curie. She was very willing. In the end she done well financially out of it, despite her protestations.

Mummy had another observation session with Quit51, where she had to see patients who are trying to quit smoking. Soon she'll be able to run these sessions herself. We still await her essay results.

Meanwhile Daddy went to parkrun, met with Farmor and later Jessica. A trip down to the Canal caf was required to replenish stocks. Jessica had chips! Route

Jessica playing with Farmor at FLP

In the afternoon we all came together again at the house. We had a visit from Ma Ma, Pop Pop and Joey. The main event was still to come. Mayhem for the next 18 hours. A Benny Sleepover party! It started at 4pm with Oli, Yuv, Kieron, Freddie and Callum all around for the night. After a spot of PS4, we all went over to the Rec to play football. Mummy ran for 25 minutes as part of her 'couch to 5km' plan. They played World Cup then a game of 3 v 3.

Pizza for tea and a combination of playing in the back garden (football and trampoline) and Rocket League on the PS4 wailed the hours away long into the night. Freddie went home early, Callum slept, but the rest stayed up all night. No sleep!

Football down the rec

title.value: Ben Shopping, parkrun, Mummy Quit51, Katie Marie Curie help, Ben Wake-over

info.content:
Ben and 7 of his mates completed a 5km course having tied their ankles together. It was a 3 legged race on steroids! It was a charity event at school.

Ben and his 7 friends tied together

Ben is going through an interesting phase with his friends at the moment. The other week, they went down the rec to play football, only for another group of boys that they know came along and started stealing the ball from them and then it descended into verbal and physical bullying. The other group of boys got reprimanded from the school. So having been on the receiving end you'd thought they would be sensitive to some bullying behaviour. However, a new friend was tagging along with Ben's gang. However, the rest of Ben's gang were not nice to him, calling him things and tripping him up and stuff. Not really bad, but enough to make this boy cry. Ben stood up for this boy telling his 5 or 6 mates that it was not fair and basically saying it was unacceptable behaviour. The rest of the gang then started taking the mick out of Ben and dismissing / laughing off his protests. This made Ben cry. Ben apologised to the boy on behalf of the gang, even though he was not involved in the bullying. Ben tried to make up with the rest of the group, but they still dismissed him. Again Ben cried as they didn't seem to care for his feelings.

Both Mummy and Daddy were exceptionally proud of Ben's attitude and handling of the situation. He was sensitive to what was right and wrong and prepared to be mocked by his closest buddies for this. He questioned his friendship to them also. If they were not going to change their views he didn't see a future with them. Such a mature, strong, stance on shoulders so young.

The morning after he received apologies from the rest of the gang and he made up with them. He was seriously going to cancel this weekend's sleepover he had planned. He skipped football training tonight and went for a bike ride with Daddy instead.

title.value: Ben standing up for a friend

info.content:
Mother's Day and we awoke in the Weston household and gave Ma Ma a nice breakfast before we had to rush home for church.

Then Mummy was pampered and treated. Katie made lunch and gave mummy a bath, whilst Ben went out for a lunchtime jog. Later in the afternoon we all watched 'Dirty Rotten Scoundrels' which we found entertaining.

Daddy was flogging his guts out in Cwmbran, mountain biking. He did two trails: Twrch and Cafall. They were tough.

Route

From Katie

From Jessica

From Ben

A full weekend ahead. Daddy had stayed at the Elders last night as he had an early start to make Merthyr Tydfil for 9am. Charlotte had stayed over last night. The Elders came over before we all headed to Gravesend. Pop Pop took us 6 children to Cascades swimming which was good fun.

Meanwhile as a Mother's Day present to Ma Ma, her three daughters 'treated' her to a Escape Room experience. Basically you have to solve a series of clues to escape the room within an hour. It was themed as a panic room. We think Ma Ma strangely enjoyed it.

Panic Room, Gravesend

Later in the afternoon there was a split; Katie, Ellie, Lily, Ma Ma went off to Bluewater for some retail therapy, Mummy, Toby, Pop Pop and Jessica watched Toy Story, the boys were of course on the computer.

Daddy arrived at Bike Park Wales, a downhill mountain biking facility joining up with Michael's Alton friends and Nick. He felt a bit out of depth as everyone had their multi thousand pound bikes, armour, all sorts of kit. Daddy on the other hand had a borrowed bike, no armour, no kit. Still eventually they all made it to the top of the hill courtesy of the 'uplift' service, a 15 minute minibus ride. And down they go, first tackling a number of 'blue' runs, before extending themselves on the 'red' trails. Daddy was amazed how much punishment the bike could take in terms of the speed over the terrain. Like a 4x4 truck. There were some seemingly quick bits, although looking on the video it seemed reasonably steady.

Back wheel jumped up strangely

Daddy fell off properly just the once. A scratch on the leg and fortunately no damage to the bike which was borrowed off an old work colleague, Tim.

Some of the Bike Park Wales possy

title.value: Swimming with Pop Pop, Shopping, Bike Park Wales, Panic Room

info.content:
As a Christmas Present Mummy got Daddy a couple of Rob Brydon tickets. Performing in the Anvil theatre, Basingstoke, they first had a warm up comedian who was very good. Then they were treated to Rob Brydon who got his observations about middle-age out of the way quickly, and spent the rest of his time toying with the crowd. By the end, he was improvising songs about their lives. He took the micky out of Tadley, and said Basingstoker's aspired to be in Winchester! He sang, took requests, gave impressions,and told anecdotes. Thoroughly entertaining.

Mummy and Daddy before going out

Rob Brydon on stage

So the big day. Daddy has been eating well for the past 2 weeks, training harder for the past 4 or 5 weeks. No cakes, no beer, not even Cornflakes of an evening. Early night, warm-up run early, extra glucose levels vigilance, no big runs during the week, breakfast 3 hours before. All text book preparation. Daddy deffo aiming for 2 hours. The secondary target was to beat Richard who was also aiming for sub 2 hours. Charlotte was also running. Conversely she hadn't trained, drank beer the night before, had a late night and not much breakfast. Other runners included: Ellie, Richard, Rachel and the rest of the Frimley Flyers crew, so a big turn out.

Daddy early tactic of keeping Richard in his sites soon disappeared within the first kilometre. Richard was away and gone and smashed his PB in a time of 1:52. Ellie and Charlotte ran together for the first 10 miles and did amazingly well coming in at 2:08 and 2:18 respectively. Absolutely fantastic considering they both have never run the distance before. Rachel also came in at 2:08.

Daddy was feeling rough at 9km, getting pins and needles in his legs and was ready to give up. However,a disgusting gel later, that feeling had dissipated and he got back on track at 11km. Daddy ran every kilometre under 6min and his fastest km was the 21st and last. Route

Daddy, Ellie and Chardo

Frimley Flyers

Fleet High Five in the High Street

A good mornings work had by all. We all went off to the Sanders household for Sausages and pizza.

Mummy and Daddy went to parkrun. Ben then played football at Heatherside and lost 7-0.

Ben's football

In the afternoon there was a girls shopping trip to M and S for Katie's clothes, then a subsequent trip into Camberley to get Jessica some stationary things!

The Maisey's came over for dinner and a sleepover. We had a 3 hour game of Monopoly which Charlotte won.

Marathon Monopoly game

title.value: parkrun, Football, Girls shopping trips, Maisey's over

info.content:
Jessica was excited to be going away for 2 nights with the school to Leeson House, near Swanage. Daddy waved her off as the two coaches wisked off yesterday.

Below is an account from school written today.

We all arrived safely at Leeson House at just before 12 yesterday. When we arrived we had a fire drill and the children found out who they would be sharing rooms with. There were no complaints about rooms and everyone seemed very happy.

A lot of children commented on how great they thought the house was and how comfortable the rooms are. The children made their own beds without too much trouble.

In the afternoon we went for a walk to Dancing Ledge, through fields and the local village. Unfortunately, we were not blessed with the warm sunny weather you had. It stayed dry but there was a persistent mist in the air. When we got to Dancing Ledge we could barely see the beautiful views we had hoped for. Along the way we enjoyed local tales of priests and smugglers. The village is stunning, particularly the church.

In the evening we had a lovely dinner of sausages, beans and jacket potatoes with chocolate sponge for dessert.

After dinner, we went back outside and enjoyed story telling around a campfire and a geology workshop looking at different types of rocks and fossils.

After hot chocolate everyone was ready for their beds

title.value: Jessica - School overnight trip - Leeson House

info.content: Mummy started her new job today as a School Nurse, band 4, until she passes her course, then it'll be a band 6. Whatever that means! So she will be shadowing someone doing her band 6 role. She was welcomed in the Ashford office with presents which settled her in nicely. She already knows the staff having worked there before. We wait for 2 weeks to see if she passed her course or not. At least there will be an income again. First for 6 months.

Daddy went for a long run in the morning and didn't do so well he thought. He struggled to complete 11 miles. In the afternoon he finished off the painting of the hall and stairwell.

Meanwhile the rest of us went to a trampoling park in Chatham for Alice's 10th birthday. After we popped into Ma Ma and Pop Pops for a spot of tea before returning home.

In the morning Mummy and Daddy went to parkrun, then Ben had football which was played at Kings College, Camberley. It was a really well fought game. Ben played well and tried hard, but narrowly lost.

In the afternoon Ben went over to play at Kieron's whilst Mummy and Daddy had a one hour stint each collecting for Marie Curie at the Meadows.

Meanwhile the girls went down to Littlehampton with Ellie and Lily to do a Zumbathon with Rachel. Jessica lasted an hour before she got bored and made her own routine up. Katie lasted the whole session. Well done girls. Because they returned back so late, they stayed at the Elders for the night.

Camberley v Mytchett

title.value: parkrun, football, Marie Curie collecting, Zumbathon, Elder sleepover

info.content:
In the afternoon Daddy and Ben went over to Swinley Forrest to go Mountain Biking

Swinley Forrest with Ben

In the morning we had parkrun and Ben's football.

Later in the afternoon we had Toby and Lily over to babysit whilst Ellie and Michael went to do an Escape Room. Ben and Toby got on really well playing Lego, drones, computer games and of course played in the park together.

Ben and Toby See-Sawing

In the morning Daddy met with Michael, Steve and Nick for a Rockets ride around the Dilley Lane circuit. It seems to be an annual trip now. The normal banter and cup of coffee at the end. Route

Dawg did keep up

Line-up

After a roast pork lunch we headed straight out for Walk 87. It was out of the Surrey book. We headed right to the other end of the county and to Bletchingley. Of course we got a little lost and made the walk 4 miles. Daddy seemed to attract a lot of sheep as we were aimlessly wandering around a farmers field lost! We finally made it back to the car. We stopped off for treats at the sweet shop on the way home! Route

The boys

Girls waiting for the boys

Jessica wandering through a farmers field

Castle Hill, Bletchingley

Later in the evening we did our various homeworks, mummy and daddy did their excercises and we had a snacky dinner.

In the morning, mummy and daddy went off to parkrun for the usual fair of slogging ones guts out and a couch to 5km, run / walk.

They quickly moved on with the rest of us to Ben's football over in Hartley Wintney. Ben played quite well and the score-line flattered the opposition at 6-1. Man of the Match was awarded to Ben which he was happy about.

Man Of The Match

Ben taking on Hartley Wintney

We moved straight on to the Aquadrome in Basingstoke for some swimming fun with the rest of the Weston family, plus a very gorgeous Oakley and mum Sues. There were a couple of slides open, as well as the lazy river. We had good fun playing.

We departed for home. In the evening mummy and daddy watched 'Girl in the Train', which mummy enjoyed having read the book.

title.value: parkrun, Hartley Wintney V Mytchett, Basingstoke Aquadrome,

info.content:
Daddy went over to Reading to play Steve at squash. It was a very enjoyable game despite the 6-1 score line. They then moved on to the gym and did a standard circuit that Steve does. For two days afterwards, Daddy's arms were aching!

Dawg Squash

In the morning Daddy went out with his old work colleague, Tim. He was lending Daddy his full suspension mountain bike. Daddy never been on one before and first impressions were great. It felt so smooth, like a slipper, soft and very comfortable (if Daddy wore slippers). They went around Swinley Forest which has changed a lot in the past 10 years, the last time Daddy went. There were marked out routes at different difficulty levels. Route

Ben made some cakes!

Ben the tart

In the afternoon some of Katie's school friends came for a sleepover. They were taken in to Camberley to watch a film at the cinema, then have a bite to eat at Frankie and Benny's. In the evening they were playing hide and seek with themselves and their phones. the last survivor stayed up until 4am! No school in the morning fortunately.

title.value: Katie Friends Sleepover, Daddy at Swinley

info.content:
A busy day. First up was a parkrun for Daddy and a Couch to 5km session for Mummy.

Ma Ma and Pop Pop briefly turned up, Pop Pop joining us at the big football match, Alton Huskies v Mytchett Kestrels or Joey v Ben. It was a league match between the two, parents were just hoping the boys would get decent game time. Fortunately (or not) there were the bare 9 players for Mytchett, meaning Ben played the whole game. Alton took an early lead and pressed hard in the first 5 or 10 minutes. Mytchett and Ben got into the game strongly after that but could not make the pressure count. Ben knew 3 or 4 of the Alton players. He was trying his hardest, making lots of runs. There were a few moments when Ben and Joey were competing for the ball, however, Joey was in defence and Ben in midfield so their paths did not cross often. Mr Martin Aves and Owen popped over to also watch which was very nice to see. In the end Alton won 2-0, Ben close to tears for a brief moment, not happy with the result. Good game.

Ben sprinting, Joey on looking

Martin and Owen playing their football

Midfield miestro

Joey turning against Ben

All's fair in the end

After the game we were invited back to Martin's for a cup of tea and saw Vicky which was very nice. After we went over to the Elders for some delicious lunch and another cuppa or two. Always nice and lively.

Later in the evening Daddy took the Fars to Heathrow airport for their trip to Argentina, Uruguay, Falklands Islands and Chile.

title.value: parkrun, Alton v Mytchett U12s, Avesy, Elders, Heathrow taxi

info.content:
Summer came over for a sleepover. Katie and her went in to Camberley for some retail therapy and to have something to eat in Frankie and Benny's. Later we went over to Gravity Force where they bounced their way around the trampoline park with Ben as well. Mummy and Daddy were relegated to watching.

Gravity Force

Meanwhile Jessica went over to Alice's to play. They went rollerskating. However, poor Alice fell over and went to hospital with a suspected broken arm. So Jessica went to Ma Ma and Pop Pops.

title.value: Summer sleepover here. Jessica at Alice's

info.content:
We awoke with love hearts themed sweets for us children. Meanwhile Mummy got some Gucci Rush perfume, the Berkshire Walk book and some chocolates. Daddy got a smart jumper. In the evening they had (supermarket bought) Chinese and Indian meals and watched Bridget Jones Baby.

22nd Valentines

We swapped Ben for Toby on our way to Ma Ma and Pop Pops. Ben was still not feeling 100%. We dropped Daddy off on the way there as he wanted to do a 10 mile run from Pedham Place Golf to Ma Ma and Pop Pops. Route . Whilst Daddy was running we went to St Nicholas church, Southfleet, for the morning service.

Pop Pop cooked a delicious pie which only the adults ate, because us children are too fussy! In the afternoon we played games like Charades and watched lots of episodes of Friends!

Ma Ma - Making a fashion statement

title.value: Ma Ma and Pop Pop's Sunday Lunch

info.content:
It was a freezing cold morning, bitterly cold. Ben had an early kick off at Harpers Lane. He wasn't feeling too great and in fact only lasted 5 minutes in the game before having to be substituted and spent the rest of the game in the car warming up. He was feeling under the weather. The team lost 6-1!

After we returned home for a warm up and fry up, Mummy had taken Katie to meet with Ma Ma and Summer. They were treated to a swim at Larkfield, near Maidstone. Ma Ma could not believe they took over 45 minutes to get ready afterwards.... and Summer hadn't even dried her hair by that stage! Later in the afternoon they went ice skating in Gillingham. They were spoilt!

Meanwhile, the children merry-go-round continued. Ben was off to the Elders for Joey's 12th birthday party where he first played football and computer around his house and 6 or 7 of his friends. In return Mummy and Auntie Charlotte took Toby and Jessica around some shops. We had Toby for a sleepover. He played very well with Jessica. They played Lego, Barbies, computer games had sweeties, watched Sponge Bob, had a bath, dinner and stories at bedtime.

Daddy took Jessica over to Gravity Force where Joey was having the evening part of his birthday. Jess joined in with Lily for an hour and a half of jumping around! They had a great time. Ben stayed for the sleepover.

Gravity Force

title.value: Football, Charlotte Over, Toby sleepover, Joey Birthday Trampolining, Katie-Summer-MaMa

info.content:
In the morning we went to church.

In the afternoon Daddy and Ben went for a bike ride around the back of the canal.

Bike Route

Woods bike ride

In the morning Daddy along with Mummy to Frimley Lodge park. Daddy to do parkrun and Mummy to do her couch to 5km, which is a mixture of running and walking for half an hour.

Ben had his first football game in ages. He played in centre midfield to begin with, then a little wider in the second half. He setup the winning goal with 5 minutes to go so came home well pumped and happy.

Ben line-up

After lunch we all went to Farnborough to do 40 mins of shopping. Jessica wanted to go to the new Smyths Toy Shop. It was packed. We then played another board game gathered from the Fars, 'And There Off'. It was a betting based game. Another thumbs up. Later in the afternoon Ellie, Lily and Toby came around for a cuppa. They stole Katie who stayed for a sleepover.

title.value: parkrun, Ben Football, Farnborough, Board game, Elders

info.content:
We played the next board game, Hotel, which was another hit.

Hotel

We left the Maisey's after a delicious breakfast and headed home. After church, we went to the Fars for a nice lunch spread, Lasagne or Pizza.

Fars Lunch

After lunch we went for a family photo shoot which Susan got the Fars for a present. Us children loved it in front of the camera.

Photo shoot

The Fars were getting rid of a lot of old board games that Daddy played when he was younger. One of which was a game called Gibberish. We had a big game and all had a laugh at the stupid sentences that were made up.

Gibberish

The Fars

info.content:
Last night we travelled down after Katie and Jessica's trampolining lesson and slept at the Maisey's.

We all got up early to get across to Lymington Woods parkrun for a 9am start. Daddy, Charlotte and Loz all did the parkrun, Mummy did her 'run and walk' for half and hour. Daddy paced Charlotte around for a 27:30 time. All us children were too lazy to do any exercise! parkrun Route

Lymington parkrun

We moved directly on from the parkrun to walk 86, starting from the village centre in Burley. It was a 4 miler which took in some really mud bits. Lenny dog loved it. At mile 3 we split between the brave (and stupid) and the not so brave (and cowards). Mummy, Katie, Ben and Jess carried on through the puddles and mud along the official route, whilst Daddy and the Maisey's went the road route. We only got lost once through Mummy's directions! Along the way we saw a dead dear which was a bit of a shock for us all! We re-convened in Burley and went into the old fashioned sweet shop to be rewarded with, ern.... sweets. Walk 86 - Route

Burley Walk with Maisey's

We popped back to the Maisey abode to get changed before going out into Bournemouth town and a spot of retail therapy. We got fish and chips at Harry Ramsdens and sat on the beach to eat. Ben got some new trainers, he's now into a size 2 and we got a Shakeaway, or McDonalds milkshake for Mummy and us girls went on the trampolines by the pier.

Beach combers

Daddy and Benny

Back at the Maisey's we had a big spag boll and watched the TV.

title.value: Weekend with Maisey's, Walk 86: Burley, Lymington parkrun, Bournemouth

info.content:
Katie got a very good school report today. We are especially happy with her effort and behaviour. Well done Katie.

Katie Report Page 1

Katie Report Page 2

It was -6 degrees on the start line at 9am for the inaugural Farnborough Winter Half Marathon. It was very cold as he lined up with the other Frimley Flyers hoping for a 2 hour trot. He ran with Oli and Dave Peddle for the first 10 miles. It was Oli's first semi-official half. The first 4 miles were a little tedious going around laps, but the best bit was at mile 8-ish when they ran down the canal into the bright sunshine. A real wintery scene with lots of runners puffing steam and the sun reflecting off the water. Daddy pushed at 10 miles but it was not enough to get in under 2 hours. Still very happy.

Just crossed the finish line

Daddy at mile 2.

The finishing Flyers

Later in the afternoon Mummy went to great grandmas to help her have a bath. The Elders popped by also. Katie wanted to get a couple more 'reflective' shots for her photography competition. So Jessica was modelling again in the back garden and daddy had to get wet feet in a puddle.

Jessica

Where's the real Daddy?

Poor Jessica has been off all week with a nasty cough. She hasn't been sleeping too well as a result. Daddy went to Frimley Lodge parkrun in -5 degrees - the rest of us didn't dare go outside.

Later in the afternoon we went for our first family walk in a long time, mainly down to Katie and Jessica's recent illnesses. Because of Jessica's recovery, we attempted a short 2 miler near the River Hamble between Southampton and Portsmouth. It was bitterly cold. Katie had a photography project to complete. The topic was 'reflection'. She got a good picture of Jessica with a pair of glasses and a swan. Route

In the evening we had Spaghetti Bolognese cooked by Daddy and watched the film Eddie The Eagle.

Jessica in reflective mood

Daddy and Benjamin

It had been raining for 24 hours. It was cold, windy and bleak out. However, Daddy decided to join Chris, Andy and Darren on a 17km trail run along the North Downs way starting and ending at the Shepherd and Flock. It was tough and Daddy was numb with cold after. It hurt warming up in the car after.... It was a struggle to walk for the rest of the day. Route

Darren, Andy, Daddy and Chris - 17km North Downs trail.

In the afternoon Daddy continued to decorate Jessica's room. A mirror image of Katie's choice. White with one wall being pink. She loved it, despite being a bit poorly.

In the morning Daddy met with Emma and Phil at parkrun. It was Emma's first ever parkrun so Daddy tried to give all the support he could for her. She did very well and proud that she did not stop and walk at the end - would have been so easy to do so. Well done Emma.

Daddy running with Emma

Mummy and Jessica were treated to a haircut, first in a long while. Mummy went for a style change.

After lunch we went to the church's New Years Party, with Farmor and the Elders. Ma Ma and Pop Pop also popped in for a bit. The usual mix of children's games and quizzes. Good fun.

Church New Year Party

In the evening we watched the film Scorch Trials. Ben has just finished reading the book with Mummy.

Daddy however went to London with Auntie Susan and the Fars. It was the Fars Christmas present to be taken out by their children to the only Danish restaurant in the country! The food was very good.... not 100% traditional danish, but good nonetheless.

Snaps and Rye

info.content:
In the morning Daddy went for an 11 mile with the Jo Longmuir training camp and struggled! Meanwhile the rest of us went to church as per usual.

In the afternoon Daddy continued in Jessica's bedroom, painting the walls white. Us 3 girls went over to the Ikea over in Theale to get some ideas on new furniture. We slipped in a few nik naks along the way.

title.value: Long run. church, Ikea, Jessica room decorating

info.content:
Today was a busy one. First up Daddy went off to parkrun. The FF theme was the orange tops and the team all ran together.

Meanwhile Jessica's room was being cleared for re-decoration, so the landing was awash with 'stuff'.

Ben played football at Harpers Lane, and again played well when he had the ball at his feet. He just didn't get involved enough. Too many times he was 10 yards behind play not busting a gut to get where he should. Anyway he was enjoying himself.

The Elders popped over for some lunch, a cuppa and a natter. Katie had met with her friends in Camberley and went shopping with them.

Later in the afternoon we all went off to John Nike Leisure centre where we did do-nutting. This was a Christmas present from Steve for all the Barnett related children.... and some of the adults.

Doughnuts

Ski slope

Ahh finished

Watching the ice hockey after

It was good fun. We first went down in singles, then as the session went on we got more adventurous until the end when we all went down together.

info.content:
Mummy had applied to go on the Peter Gordon's Breakfast show, Face Off quiz versus Ben on Eagle Radio. We had a phone call a few days before to say that the application was successful and that they would be on the radio at 7:45am. If they lost they would have to sacrifice something. Ben would give up his PS4 for a week, whilst mummy would give up reading her book! Mummy was nervous beforehand just in case she said something embarrassing, whilst Ben took it in his stride, although a little nervous.

The questioning went:

  • Ben, what substance is represented by the chemical symbol H20?
  • Ben: Water.
  • Laura, what ground does Manchester United play at?
  • Laura: Old Trafford. We did a tour there last year.
  • Tie Breaker: How many medals did GB win at the Rio Olympics?
  • Laura: 50
  • Ben: 52
  • Ben's the winner. Congratulations.

Peter Gordon's Breakfast Show, Face Off Quiz, Eagle Radio. So Ben wasn't 100% sure on the Water answer, he thought maybe just Hydrogen... and he thought 52 was the correct answer. Anyway mummy said she would stick to her book ban for a week!

title.value: Mummy V Ben, Peter Gordon Breakfast Show, Face Off Quiz, Eagle Radio

info.content:
First day back after Christmas holiday's and Daddy crashed his motorbike half a mile away just past the railway by the church. He was going about 15 mph and lost control, snaking up the road without slowing down as he was slipping on ice. He landed on the correct side of the road thankfully and was not hit by anyone. He hurt his leg enough to be limping. He struggled to lift the bike off the road, a fellow motorist helped it up and parked it at the side of the road. Oil was leaking out, the brake level was broken and their were of course scrape marks up the bike. No other damage. The bike wouldn't start so had to push it to the church and await the recovery truck! Daddy worked at home.

Motorbike crash site
